awd_titl_txt: XUV Frequency Combs for Precision Spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will utilize precision frequency comb spectroscopy  in the vacuum-ultraviolet (VUV) and extreme ultraviolet (XUV) to investigate atomic and molecular transitions that have significant value in increasing our understanding of fundamental physics. A new method utilizing two phase-coherent XUV femtosecond frequency combs will be investigated as a promising path towards high-resolution spectroscopy with unprecedented accuracy in this difficult to reach spectral region. The physics to be explored in this project will come from two distinct objectives: (1) to elucidate how the physics underlying intracavity high harmonic generation affects the conversion efficiency and noise characteristics of the XUV femtosecond frequency comb, and (2) to utilize the dual-XUV frequency comb approach to provide an improved measurement of high-n Rydberg states (n~50-60) in molecular hydrogen, thereby providing an improved value for the ionization and dissociation energy of this physically important molecular system.

This program will provide a unique research-based education for graduate students in the fundamentals of light-matter interaction, advanced laser systems, and their use to probe and better understand the most basic and common molecule: molecular hydrogen. Some of the most basic atomic and molecular systems have their first resonance in the vacuum-ultraviolet portion of the light spectrum. This is a region where few laser sources exist, making it difficult to precisely study the structure of atoms and molecules needed for testing our understanding of current physical models. This program will utilize recently developed sources and techniques to study molecular hydrogen with much greater precision, and open the door to further studies in this difficult to reach spectral region. Such research provides a solid foundation to prepare the next generation of scientists to serve in our national, academic, and industrial research laboratories.

por.por_cntn:
The broader goal of this project is to explore precision frequency comb spectroscopy of atomic and molecular transitions in the vacuum-ultraviolet (VUV) and extreme ultraviolet (XUV) that are of physical significance. A new method utilizing two phase-coherent XUV fs frequency combs is being investigated as a promising path towards high-resolution spectroscopy with unprecedented accuracy in this difficult to reach spectral region.

During the course of this resedrach we have up-converted each fs frequency comb into the VUV and XUV using their own independent fs enhancement cavity and utilizing intra-cavity high harmonic geneartion. This requires extensive laser stabilization. This technical challenge has been overcome and we have succedded in making measurements at the 3rd and 5th harmonics of the fundamental laser spectrum. This is a critical step that can be extended to high-harmonics and will enable dual-comb spectroscopy in the VUV.

We have also developed a novel technique to probe the intracavity plasma dynamically. This involves using a probe pulse train propagating in the opposite direction inside the fs enhancement cavity. The probe pulse is phase coherent with the forward propagating pulse trains (via active laser stabilization). We can easily and rapidly change the delay between the probe pulse and the ionizing laser pulses in the enhancement cavity. The probe pulse will see a nonlinear phase shift due to the residual plasma from the pump pulse that is a function of the delay. By monitoring the shift in the cavity resonance seen by the probe pulse, we can observe in real time the intracavity plasma dynamics. This is significant since we can directly observe intracavity ionization levels for the first time. The intracavity ionization levels are a fundamental limitation of intra-cavity high harmonic generation. Now that this can be carefully monitored, we hope to find strategies to mitigate the adverse affects and establish this novel source as a powerful tool for spectroscopic measuremnts in the VUV and XUV.
